item.title: Trump, Ishiba Meet at G-7 as Japan’s Leader Seeks Trade Deal
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba met on the sidelines of the Group of Seven summit on Monday, according to Japan’s government, in what is set to be a key marker of how trade talks are progressing and the impact for Ishiba’s political future.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba at the Group of Seven (G7) Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada, on June 16.

item.title: Senate Republicans Propose More Aggressive Medicaid Cuts to Help Pay for Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans are proposing cuts to the Medicaid program for low-income and disabled people that are more aggressive than policies the House passed to help pay for President Donald Trump’s sweeping tax package.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang

media:content.media:description: A healthcare professional in the ICU at Van Wert County Hospital in Van Wert, Ohio.

item.title: Trump Tax Bill to Boost Biden’s Semiconductor Tax Credit to 30%
item.description: The Senate’s draft tax bill calls for temporarily increasing an investment credit for semiconductor manufacturers, enhancing a subsidy for chipmakers to build factories in the US.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: A bare wafer stacker sorts silicon wafers in Building 51 at Micron Technology Inc. headquarters in Boise, Idaho, US, on Monday, June 10, 2024. The US announced in April its plans to award Micron Technology Inc. $6.1 billion in grants and as much as $7.5 billion in loans to help the memory-chip maker build new American factories, rounding out a slew of major federal awards for advanced semiconductor manufacturing.

item.title: Minnesota Shooting Suspect Faces US Charges Including Murder
item.description: US prosecutors charged alleged shooter Vance Boelter with two counts of murder in the deaths of Minnesota State Representative Melissa Hortman and her husband, in what officials referred to as a “murderous rampage” on Saturday morning.
item.dc:creator: Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: FBI agents in a neighborhood in Green Isle, Minnesota, on June 15. Photographer: Stephen Maturen/Getty Images

item.title: Senate Republicans Release Revised Tax Cuts and Debt Limit Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans propose to cut trillions of dollars in taxes for households and businesses in their version of President Donald Trump’s signature economic package, a plan that comes at the expense of curbing health coverage for some low-income Americans and adding to US deficits.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. Senate Republicans on Wednesday unveiled a budget blueprint designed to fast-track a renewal of President Donald Trump's tax cuts and an increase to the nation's borrowing limit, ahead of a planned vote on the resolution later this week. Photographer: Daniel Heuer/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says Iran Wants to Talk But Israel Sees More Strikes
item.description: President Donald Trump said Iran wants to talk about de-escalating the deadly conflict with Israel but that country’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, signaled strikes would continue.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Stephanie Lai, Arsalan Shahla, Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney speaks during a meeting with US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the G7 Summit, in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16. Photographer: Mark Schiefelbein/AP Photo

item.title: Starmer, Trump Agree to Implement Tariff-Cutting Trade Deal
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer reached an agreement with US President Donald Trump to implement trading terms disclosed last month to slash US tariffs on key British exports and raise UK quotas on certain American agricultural products.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump meets with Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer on the sidelines of the G7 Summit in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16. Photographer: Mark Schiefelbein/AP Photo

item.title: Rich Colleges Would Face Lower Tax Hike Under Senate Bill
item.description: Wealthy US colleges scored a win on Monday with the release of Senate Republicans’ tax bill, which would institute a lower tax increase on endowments than what GOP House members have backed.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright

media:content.media:description: The Baker Library of the Harvard Business School on the Harvard University campus in Boston, Massachusetts, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. President Donald Trump on Monday threatened to divert billions in grant dollars away from Harvard University and give those funds to trade schools across the US, escalating his clash with the elite institution.

item.title: US Won’t Back G-7’s Iran De-Escalation Push in Sign of Disunity
item.description: The US is blocking a proposed Group of Seven statement urging Israel and Iran to de-escalate their conflict, people familiar with the matter said, highlighting the distance that’s opened up between President Donald Trump and other members of the bloc.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: A working session during the Group of Seven (G7) Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada on June 16. Photographer: Michael Kappeler/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Senate Delays and Scales Back ‘Revenge Tax’ in Trump Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans plan to delay and make less onerous a levy targeting foreign companies and investors from countries that the US determines have been unfairly taxing US companies.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC. Photographer: Eric Lee/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Says Russia Sanctions Would Cost US ‘a Lot of Money’
item.description: US President Donald Trump indicated at the Group of Seven summit that he is in no rush to impose tougher sanctions on Russia, dismissing pressure from allied leaders eager to do more to push Moscow to the negotiating table.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump at the Group of Seven (G7) Summit in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada on June 16.

item.title: RFK Jr.’s Policy Moves Are Weakening Vaccine Infrastructure, Fired Advisers Say
item.description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s decision to overhaul a key committee on vaccine policy has left the country’s vaccine infrastructure “critically weakened,” former members of the group said in a piece published in JAMA on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Damian Garde, Michelle Amponsah

media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., US secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS), during a Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. The FDA and NIH are pushing out a joint research initiative that will explore nutrition issues and infant dietary exposures, fueling Kennedy's agenda to scrutinize the food supply.

item.title: Solar May Get a Dash of Hot Sauce in Senate Version of Tax Bill
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Monday, Bloomberg Intelligence senior analyst Nathan Dean gives his insights into what’s been happening and what’s coming up in the nooks and crannies of government and markets. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Nathan R Dean

item.title: Stocks Rise as Fear of All-Out Mideast War Eases: Markets Wrap
item.description: Relative calm returned to global markets, with stocks climbing and oil sinking alongside gold as fears subsided that Israel’s war against Iran would escalate into a wider conflict. News reports that Tehran wants to restart talks over its nuclear program also fueled risk-on sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Israeli rescuers search through the rubble at the site of an overnight Iranian missile strike in Bat Yam on June 15, 2025.

item.title: Democratic Senators Request Details of Upcoming Housing Meeting
item.description: A handful of Democratic senators are asking key government officials including Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent for information regarding a meeting this week where Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac may be discussed.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: The Freddie Mac headquarters in Mclean, Virginia.

item.title: Senate Deadlocked on SALT, With Draft Bill Showing Current $10,000 Cap
item.description: The Senate’s version of President Donald Trump’s tax bill calls for a $10,000 cap on the state and local tax deduction — a placeholder figure as Republicans remain divided over the valuable tax break.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune

item.title: Israel to Continue Strikes Despite Reports Iran Seeks Talks
item.description: Israel will pursue its military operations against Iran regardless of the progress of any potential negotiations involving the US, Israeli Strategic Affairs Minister Ron Dermer said in an interview on Bloomberg Television.
item.dc:creator: Courtney McBride, Joe Mathieu

media:content.media:description: Vehicles jam a highway as a fire blazes at the oil depots of Shahran, Iran, on June 15.

item.title: Oil Drops on Signs Conflict May Spare Iranian Crude Production
item.description: Oil fell on signs that the conflict in the Middle East may avoid disrupting crude production, with Iran seeking to deescalate hostilities with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Vehicles jam a highway as a fire blazes nearby in the Shahran in Tehran on June 15, 2025. Photographer: Atta Kenare/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: US Defeats Teachers Unions’ Lawsuit to Restore Columbia Funding
item.description: The Trump administration won dismissal of a lawsuit by two unions seeking to stop the withholding of $400 million in federal funds from Columbia University, saying the groups didn’t have the legal right to challenge the decision.
item.dc:creator: Chris Dolmetsch

media:content.media:description: Columbia University. 2960 Broadway corner of 116th Street, New York, Manhattan, USA. This private university, one of the oldest in the city, is among the best in the world, especially in the field of medical and scientific research. The campus was built in 1897, and today thousands of students annually passing through their classrooms. From here have come 49 Nobel laureates, a figure which not all universities can claim. The esplanade of the campus is a quiet place where students roam and which highlights the ancient LIBRARY Low Library, which is accessed via a wide staircase which lies the statue of Alma Mater.. (Photo by: Sergi Reboredo/VW Pics/Universal Images Group via Getty Images)

item.title: Harvard Judge Says Foreign Student Ban Likely to Harm School
item.description: A federal judge said that Harvard University is likely to show that it will suffer irreparable harm if the government is able to stop international students from attending the Ivy League school.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos, Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: The Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. Harvard University won a longer-term reprieve from a Trump administration ban on enrolling international students, handing the nations oldest and richest university a victory in its battle with the White House.

item.title: Most Israelis Back Iran Strikes But Are Split Over Continuing, Poll Shows
item.description: More than two-thirds of Israelis back their country’s airstrikes against Iran, though fewer than a quarter believe it’s possible to end the threat seen from Tehran’s nuclear program without US assistance, an opinion poll found.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: Fire and smoke rise into the sky after an Israeli attack on the Shahran oil depot in Tehran, on June 15.

item.title: What to Know About the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty as Iran Mulls Exit
item.description: Iran could be poised to withdraw from an international accord that seeks to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. This follows growing tensions with the United Nations’ atomic watchdog, compounded by Israel’s attacks on the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: Satellite view of the Isfahan enrichment facility following Israeli airstrikes in Iran, on Jun 14, 2025. Source: Maxar Technologies

item.title: Mali to Take Control of Key Barrick Gold Mine for Six Months
item.description: A Malian court ruled that Barrick Mining Corp.’s Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex should be placed under provisional administration for six months, handing control of one of the Canadian company’s biggest operations to state-appointed management.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Diakaridia Dembele, Jacob Lorinc

media:content.media:description: Dumper trucks collect rock ore from from the digging floor in a section of the Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: IMF Team Lands in Kenya to Assess Impact of Corruption
item.description: An International Monetary Fund mission is in Kenya for two weeks to assess the impact of corruption on public finances, with the findings expected to inform a new program requested by the government.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Nairobi, Kenya

item.title: Irish State to Exit AIB, Putting Bank Into Private Ownership
item.description: The Irish state has launched its final share sale with AIB Group Plc, reducing its stake in the lender to zero and putting it into private ownership.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: An Allied Irish Banks branch in Dublin.

item.title: G-7 Works to Secure Critical Minerals in Face of China Curbs
item.description: The Group of Seven leading economies are working to shore up supplies of critical minerals as they seek to move away from reliance on China for materials used in everything from mobile phones to wind turbines.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Bags of rare earth concentrates sit for transport at the Mountain Pass mine in Mountain Pass, California.

item.title: Trump Orders ICE to Expand Deportations in Largest Cities Including New York and Chicago
item.description: President Donald Trump directed federal officials to expand efforts to deport migrants in the largest US cities in the face of protests and court challenges, even as his administration is looking to ease the impact of the crackdown on key sectors of the American workforce.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Federal agents detain an individual following a hearing in immigration court at the Jacob K. Javitz Federal Building in New York, on June 10.

item.title: US Urges Appeals Court to Allow National Guard Troops in LA
item.description: The US Department of Justice urged a federal appeals court to overturn a lower court’s order that limits the Trump administration’s use of National Guard troops in Los Angeles in response to protests over the president’s immigration raids.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: California National Guard members stand in formation during a “No Kings” protest in Los Angeles, California, on June 14, 2025.

item.title: UK-US Trade Deal Leaves Steel Tariffs in Place For Now

media:content.media:description: Attendees at the G7 Media Centre before the G7 Leaders' Summit in Banff, Alberta, on June 15. Photographer: Gavin John/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Family Launches Branded Mobile Phone Service in US
item.description: President Donald Trump’s family is getting into the mobile phone business with a Trump-branded service that will rely on pre-existing wireless networks and hardware that is “made in America.”
item.dc:creator: Kelcee Griffis, Ashley Carman

media:content.media:description: Eric Trump, from left, Don Hendrickson, Eric Thomas, Patrick O’Brien, and Donald Trump Jr. during an announcement for Trump Mobile in New York on June 16.
